intro: Chaenorhinum grossecostatum, commonly known as the broad-ribbed nightshade, is a flowering plant native to southern Europe and western Asia. It belongs to the Solanaceae family, which includes tomatoes, potatoes, and peppers, and is characterized by its toxic alkaloids. The plant produces small, bell-shaped flowers that are typically purple or white, and it has hairy, ribbed stems and broad, ovate leaves. It thrives in sunny, well-drained soils and is often found in rocky or dry habitats. Due to its toxic properties, it is not recommended for cultivation in gardens or around livestock.
